notes:
Happy one year anniversary for the Personality Swap AU! I made sure to post today, so I hope you all enjoy! <3

(See the end of the work for more notes.)

So, what did you think? I hope it was worth the wait!
...and speaking of waits, I'd just like to warn you guys that the next update *might* take a bit longer to post. My work is having its biggest sale of the year this week, so I've been a little overbooked, and next week I'm going away for a few days with family, so I likely won't have time to write. I hope this makes up for the delay!

Finally, as a treat, here's what I think the students of 1-A did for their projects!

Aoyama- Cheese presentation ft. tastings
Ashido- evolution of dance
Asui- Frogs (ft. a 'making the frogs gay' reference)
Iida- Rules
Uraraka-Space!
Ojirou-Martial arts
Kaminari-Memes
Kirishima-Crimson Riot
Kouda-How to approach a scared/wounded animal
Satou-how to make the cake he made for the dorm competition ft. more cake
Shouji-how to give good hugs
Jirou-how to play a guitar
Sero-how to make a hammock out of literally anything
Tokoyami- how to summon a demon (he gets bonus points for actually trying to summon a demon)
Todoroki-A project on the people who mean most to him. It's mainly about Midoriya, to be quite honest, but Midoriya assumes it's a friend thing at the time.
Hagakure-how to put on makeup (uses mido as a volunteer?)
Bakugou-How to make explosions ft. Hatsume's guidance
Midoriya-Acting (and how analysis and talent come into play)
Shinsou-Joke Presentation where he shows pictures of Aizawa sleeping in class (ends with Mido Aizawa sleeping bag pic), then gives actual presentation on the problems with sleep deprivation
Yaoyorozu-types of tea + their perks

Until next time! <3
text:
The year rings out, the second term ending and the third beginning with the rush of January, and Izuku Midoriya continues to work on his Quirk, slowly but surely coming to grips with his power, making it his own and gaining a sense of precision and understanding that would take most far more time. But Midoriya has had to do the same once before, already, has learned to grow exponentially compared to his peers thanks to One for All, and so the process is not quite as stressful as it could have been. It is a process that still continues, of course, his lessons with Aizawa not yet ceasing, but it is a skill that Midoriya has improved upon immensely.


But the story of today, of now, does not start with a feat of power or skill, is not a spectacle of chaos nor one of awe-inspiring acts. 


No, the story begins on a sunny but cold Monday afternoon just a few weeks into the third term, with Midoriya walking hand in hand with Eri, Aizawa on her other side, the three making their way through the city, searching for something to snack on, a treat for the young girl.


And the story begins with Midoriya telling a story of his own, an explanation of the day that has passed. 


Currently, the boy is talking about a part that especially worries him, plaguing his mind. Not that something bad has happened, no. No, no one has been harmed, or upset in a way that is unsettling. 


No, it is just a stressful thing that happens in schools everywhere. A normal project, nothing more, nothing less, and yet Midoriya stresses over it in the same way that he has feared villains- perhaps moreso, considering that he is allowed to punch villains but not destroy the assignment he must complete.


Even so, Midoriya takes the walk as a chance to explain his worries, going over them with Aizawa and Eri, who listen along attentively.


“But Kayama-sensei says that our presentation has to be about something that is both informative and interesting,” Midoriya says, his free hand reaching up to tug at a lock of hair, pulling it back only for it to spring back into place. “And I was thinking about doing a lesson on analysis, but I don’t really know how to make analyzing a hero... fun to watch, you know? I mean, it’s usually just me scribbling down notes, and I don’t usually show people those, and I know Nedzu finds them interesting but that’s the finished result! I don’t think that my friends would want to just...sit there as I write notes on heroes.”


Aizawa hums, nods along, because he understands the concerns that his kid is fretting over. “You could always use one of your peers as an on the spot example, and then analyze them,” Aizawa suggests. “I’m sure that one of your friends would volunteer for the role.”


“It’d make them excited!” Eri agrees. “They could get picked by 

you

!”


“I know a good damn lot of them would love 

that

,” Aizawa mutters to himself, but neither Midoriya nor Eri hear him.


Instead, Aizawa speaks up, voice louder so as to be heard, and says, “You could also increase their participation by asking them to help analyze the volunteer. It would make them more invested in the outcome.”


“But they might feel like it’s an extra assignment for them,” Midoriya counters. “I don’t want to push that onto them, especially once the more obvious traits are picked. If I ask for their input, I want to make it easy on them- they’ll already be stressed over their own presentations, after all!”


Aizawa blinks at Midoriya’s worried expression, not surprised by the boy’s unwillingness to even 

potentially

 place more stress on his friends. Really, he should have known.


"Then perhaps let them steer the discussion by choosing topics. Then they can have input, but they won't be supplying the answers."


Midoriya hums, nods along. "That would help...but I think I have a better idea?"


And Aizawa is always glad to see Midoriya have confidence in himself, so for the boy to hint that whatever he has in mind to be superior to Aizawa’s?


Aizawa is more than happy to nod along, listening.


And so Midoriya tells, lets his idea be known and Aizawa smiles, because it is an idea so truly in character for his Problem Child and Aizawa cannot 

wait

 to ask Nedzu for the security footage later that day.


Kami knows he will enjoy the results.


“So you have your idea?” Eri asks, when Midoriya is done explaining and Aizawa is left grinning like a madman.


“I think so, yeah!” Midoriya says, and Eri cheers.


“Great!” A pause, and then, “Can we go get mochi?”


(They get mochi.)


(And, as it always does, the story continues.)


-----


The story continues, Monday turning to Tuesday, and the class of 1-A is left stressing over the recently assigned project from Kayama.


But a statement such as that would imply an equally shared feeling of stress, would indicate that none of 1-A is prepared in any way, shape, or form. And this belief would be incorrect, because some do have ideas, even if their thoughts are not quite set in stone, not fully etched into their paths.


Still, it is a beginning, and beginnings are beautiful things, important things that shape fate incredibly. And so these beginnings are treasured, especially compared to those who panic blindly, unsure of their future.


(Let it not be said that the class of 1-A is not as dramatic as their supernova peer known best as Izuku Midoriya. For they surely are, even if in a different form of the meaning, a different approach to the matter.)


The students of 1-A sit around the classroom, perched at their desks, or clumped near those of their friends, as they wait for Yamada to enter the room and teach them English, and they speak as a group, the conversation following their school days.


And so it is inevitable that the topic comes up, with Tooru Hagakure being the one to ask, “Hey, guys? What do you plan to talk about for Kayama-sensei’s project? I’m still stuck in the brainstorming process.”


And at first the students of 1-A pause, because they are unsure of who has plans and who does not, and who will want to share their ideas first. Most do not know, unfortunately, or perhaps have not yet bothered to decide, having put the process off for the evening.


But then Tsuyu Asui speaks, drawing attention to her like honey does flies, a comparison that does not suit the mind well when talking of a girl with a frog mutation.


“I want to teach you guys about something related to water rescues, 

kero

.” Tapping a finger to her cheek, Asui adds, “Although I might switch to talking about frogs- there’s a lot of frogs that you guys might find interesting.”


“Like what?” Hagakure asks, and Asui hums.


“Well, some use color to turn invisible.”


“I want twenty,” Hagakure says instantly, and the two laugh. 


“Well, I’m going to be teaching you guys about memes!” Denki Kaminari chimes in, then leans forwards on his desk to shoot Iida a fake glare. “Because 

someone

 would fail if he had to finish a vine reference on the spot!”


“Kaminari!” Tenya Iida says, face red as he adjusts his glasses. “Are you sure that fits the criteria of being informative?”


“I’ll be informing 

you

, won’t I?”


“I-” Iida sputters, chops his arms. “You already have informed me! On the day that we swapped personalities, in fact, you gave me a quick course on the matter!”


“And yet I bet my 

other

 swap learned more memes on his own!” Kaminari challenges. Iida freezes, then glances at Shouto Todoroki, who stares idly back. 


“I am sure that we are both equally informed in such a subject,” Iida says, and Hitoshi Shinsou snorts.


“Right. Alright, finish this reference, then,” Shinsou offers, and then, after a pause, simply says, “Jared.”


“He never learned how to read,” Todoroki says somberly as Iida stares in confusion.


“That was a reference?” Iida asks, and then drops his head. “I suppose the lecture will be informative, after all.”


“I think I’m going to teach you guys about space!” Ochako Uraraka chimes in, bright eyed at the very idea. “Or maybe I’ll just pull a page out of Deku’s book and talk about Thirteen!”


“Then maybe I should talk about Crimson Riot!” Eijirou Kirishima realizes. “I’ve been coming up empty handed whenever I’ve thought of it so far, this could work!” Turning to Katsuki Bakugou, Kirishima asks, “What do you plan to do, Bakubro?”


And Bakugou smirks, letting out a scoff and saying, “I’m teaching you idiots about explosions.”


“We already know about your Quirk,” Shinsou says dryly, and Bakugou scowls at the boy.


“No, you fucking insomniac! I’m going to show you how to make your fucking own!” Aiming a pointed look at Midoriya, Bakugou adds, “

Without

 using my gauntlets- or my sweat in general.”


“Should I ask?” Kaminari murmurs, and Midoriya laughs.


“I’ve been trying to test some stuff with his Quirk, and Kacchan has been my volunteer to work on my theories.”


“He volunteered?” Uraraka asks.


“No I didn’t!” Bakugou shouts, and then huffs, looking away. “Stupid nerd was going to try using 

his

 Quirk to mimic mine, all based on some theories he came up with thanks to the 

rat

. I wasn’t going to risk watching him get hurt 

again

, then he’s not good at sparring. I need a real fucking fight.”


“So compassionate,” Kirishima murmurs. 


“So you’re teaching us about how to make explosions? How are you getting that approved?” Momo Yaoyorozu asks, her expression one of vague concern. “Surely our teachers won’t just let you use the necessary materials blindly, right?”


“They 

did

 give Kacchan gauntlets that allow him to store his own sweat without any requirements,” Midoriya points out helpfully, and Yaoyorozu blanches.


“Ah, right.” Clearing her throat, the vice representative asks, “Are you taking any precautions of your own, Bakugou?”


“Eighteen plus said I needed to work with a Support nerd to make sure I knew how to contain everything,” Bakugou says, and then smiles widely, the look off putting and dangerous. “So I went to Deku’s little friend- we’re testing the different blast sizes today.”


And the students of 1-A do not know what is more frightening- the fact that Bakugou is teaming up with a girl like Mei Hatsume, who they have a much more distinct impression of ever since Midoriya impersonated the girl.


Or the encouraging smile that Midoriya is giving Bakugou.


“That’s great!” Midoriya chirps. “Hatsume has been a bit stressed lately, this will be a great way for her to let off some steam!”


Perhaps the answer is both. Especially with how the boys are grinning at one another.


Thinking it best to change the conversation, Shinsou turns to Midoriya and asks, “So, what do you plan to do?”


“Oh, you know,” Midoriya says vaguely. “Something fun!”


And the answer answers nothing at all for 1-A, the class knowing their peer as they do. And so his peers turn to him, hoping to get a better answer out of him.


Only for the bell to ring, Yamada stepping into the room.


And so Tuesday comes and goes, and the story goes onwards all the more.


-----


And Wednesday speeds by, the day itself moving in the blink of an eye, and then the bell is ringing at the end of the day and the students of 1-A are preparing to head back to the dorms.


All except for one, for Izuku Midoriya, who packs his bag and listens to his peers as they speak, knowing that he will be going a separate route the moment that they exit the room.


It 

is

 Wednesday, after all, a day meant to be spent with a specific principal.


(Chants of ‘rat god Wednesday’ still ring through the halls, even now. It is as ominous as it is enthralling, a delight to be had that leaves shivers down one’s spine.)


But for the moment, Izuku is not in a rush, knowing that Nedzu does not begin to make their tea until a few minutes after the bell has rung, so that their drinks are perfectly heated when Izuku walks into the room. It is just a thing that Nedzu does, a control habit, he believes. Just another aspect in life that Nedzu can alter at his own whims, but chooses to keep repetitive for the sake of repetition itself.


It’s familiar, though, and Izuku cannot blame the principal. Nedzu’s little quirks are as fascinating as his actual Quirk, even if interesting in a different way. 


But all that matters at the current moment is that Izuku is in no hurry, and so Izuku smiles and laughs along with his friends as they try to discuss their thoughts. 


Currently, they seem to be set on shaming Iida for his project idea.


“You can’t do your presentation on the school rules, Iida!” Uraraka exclaims, though the way that she can’t look Iida in the eye is a sure sign that the brunette is about to laugh. 


“It will be informative!” Iida says. “Especially to Kaminari, who does not seem to know the rules!”


“It’s not really a roast if they’re not there to hear it,” Shinsou murmurs. “And to think, you were so close.”


“Although your topic would be informative,” Asui starts, “it likely wouldn’t be entertaining, 

kero

.”


Iida’s jaw drops, and then he clicks it shut. Arm chopping, the boy says, confused, “I don’t mean to sound offensive, and my apologies if I do...but isn’t Shinsou’s plan to talk about sleep? And not even the benefits of sleep, but just- 

sleep

?” 


“It will be entertaining,” Shinsou says, smiling wryly, but Iida just shakes his head.


“And why do you all believe my topic to be so bad, when we all surely know that Todoroki is just going to talk about M-”


Izuku watches as Todoroki lights up suddenly, hair setting on fire and hand reaching out. Iida quiets immediately.


“We can’t talk about that,” Todoroki says calmly. “Not yet.”


Izuku blinks, then smiles. Perhaps Todoroki wants to talk about his mom? How sweet!


“Have you figured out your project?” Uraraka asks Izuku, and Izuku nods.


“Yeah! I’m almost done with it, actually!”


“That’s great!” Uraraka cheers, and Izuku beams.


“It is!” A quick glance at the clock tells Izuku that it’s probably time to go, so he shoulders his backpack and waves to his friends. “I’ll see you guys at the dorms!”


His friends quickly say their farewells, and Izuku exits the classroom for 1-A, then treks down to the principal’s office. The halls are already fairly empty, most students having left the moment that the bell rang, eager to head back to their dorms. This just means that the path is clear, and that Izuku is able to reach Nedzu’s office in a shorter period of time than he otherwise would have.


Izuku lifts his hand to knock on the door, and a cheerful “Come in!” reaches his ears a moment before his hand can meet wood, just as it always does.


And so Izuku enters Nedzu’s office, the creature smiling at him as he does so.


“Midoriya! Good afternoon!” Nedzu greets, and Izuku smiles back.


“Good afternoon, Nedzu!” The principal wouldn’t accept being called sensei, for whatever reason, and Izuku had grown used to the wish of his mentor. (This one of multiple, at the very least.)


Nedzu waits until Izuku has sat down to push his cup of tea his way, and Izuku takes it, hands wrapping instinctively around the mug. 


And just like that, they’ve begun. 


(And so the two will talk of many things, of those both pointless and those that mean far too much in the world. And although the world may wish to hear of such things, it is best left unspoken, unheard of. All of Yuuei knows this, even if not consciously, a reason that Nedzu’s office and the area surrounding it remains vacant for all but two, not even the teachers daring to go near the door when in need of answers.


But the two will talk, both as mentor and protege, but also as equals, two minds coming together to tear things apart and remake them. 


And one thing that they will talk of is Izuku’s growth, of how he has progressed with his Quirks since the beginning of the year, since he awakened his birth Quirk.


And although Izuku will not know it, will not be told it, not yet, Nedzu is proud of the boy’s growth.


Because the boy is growing, despite it all, and that is more than enough for the principal.


Things are changing, but Izuku is not alone, and that is a constant that will remain forevermore.)


-----


Thursday begins calmly.


Emphasis on 

begins

.


It does not stay this way, not for long. Not when the students of 1-A see Midoriya enter the room, and see that the outfit he wears is not the school’s uniform, but something else entirely.


Gone are the red shoes, replaced with normal black dress shoes. And the Yuuei uniform is replaced by a light gray suit with a white dress shirt underneath, a red tie with white dots tied perfectly as the final touch, clothing wise at least.


Accessory wise, Midoriya only adds one new item, a pair of glasses that seem to turn opaque in the right lighting, giving him an intimidating look.


And Midoriya seems to have made use of the makeup case given to him on Christmas, his hair no longer its normal curly dark green, but rather straightened, parted, and given three yellow streaks.


With a stiff gait and hands clasped behind his back, Midoriya is a man that most do not recognize.


But one that enough do. Those who participated in the raid against the Shie Hassaikai, who saw the man who was foolish enough that Midoriya rejected his internship offer to go elsewhere, the same man who was also sensible enough to apologize and make amends with their shining center, the sunshine of 1-A.


They are the ones that recognize Midoriya to be Sir Nighteye, the only former sidekick of All Might.


It’s a sign of things to come, in more ways than one.


Homeroom goes well enough, although Aizawa seems to be surprised by Midoriya’s apparel upon first glance. It’s a surprising fact, at first, given the conservative nature of Midoriya’s outfit, but giving the matter a second thought, it makes sense. Midoriya had gone to his lessons with Nedzu the day before, after all, and so Nedzu could have easily given the assignment during their allotted time. Along with this, those who went on the raid or have been told of the hero are quick to offer information to those left in the dark, explaining how Sir Nighteye had brushed Midoriya aside at first, having only seen him for his lack of control during the Sports Festival. It was a mistake Nighteye had fixed, luckily, apologizing after the raid for his assumptions, but the mistake was enough that most of 1-A doubted the man would have been considered as an assignment in Aizawa’s mind. 


So of course Aizawa would not be aware- he would not have suggested such a character, after all.


But Midoriya’s meeting with Nedzu had led to this, and so Aizawa blinks only once before nodding along, surely trusting his favored student, the boy who was practically his son, in knowing his own boundaries in terms of comfort.


And so homeroom went by, with nothing going wrong.


Quite honestly, nothing truly goes 

wrong

 on this Thursday. Midoriya’s character is a rather tame one, and it is not one chosen to torment anyone in specific. There is no hidden maliciousness or need for chaos, only a want for more practice, a chance for Midoriya to act and grow used to his Quirk.


It is more of a test for Midoriya, a test of endurance. 


And so the morning goes smoothly, none of the teachers having problems with Midoriya. Midoriya is the picture definition of polite, after all, if a little quiet. If he were in a different ensemble, perhaps he could have been considered a quiet version of Iida, with diligent notes and sharp movements, but he is not in a different outfit and so it is clear that he is someone else entirely. 


Not even Hizashi Yamada reacts poorly, the man instead offering a small smile at the sight of Midoriya in character. Because despite the many scares that Yamada has had, he is glad to see the boy growing more confident, stepping back into the spotlight and embracing the changes as a part of himself. Midoriya is moving back into the narrative, letting his acts resume, and Yamada cannot fault anyone for such a thing, cannot be upset in the slightest. 


(Because Yamada is a teacher, a good one, just like the rest of the teachers of Yuuei. And just like the others, he is happy when he sees one of his students flourishing.


And though this is not the type of teacher that Midoriya is used to, it is the type he has now, a type that he will have all throughout Yuuei. It is the type he deserves, and the type he gets.


And they will be there for him through it all.)


No, there are no issues with the teachers, but the day is not completely calm.


And it’s all because of one key moment, one that the students of 1-A will look back on and laugh over.


All except for one, to be more precise.


The incident occurs right after the bell rings for lunch, with Denki Kaminari jumping up and racing over to the professionally dressed boy. Kaminari is all but vibrating as he leans in close, his face mere inches away from Midoriya’s as he asks, “Hey, your Quirk lets you see the future, right? That’s what Kirishima told me. Can you use your Quirk on me?”


“My Quirk only works for one hour, and then it will need twenty-four hours to be usable once more,” Midoriya explains, voice bordering on cold and definitely uninterested. One eyebrow raising ever so slightly, he asks, “Is your curiosity worth it? Are your inquiries so desperate to be filled?”


“Absolutely!” Kaminari says, nodding rapidly. “Dude, it’s my 

future

! Will I look hot as an adult- ooh, does my costume ever change? How soon do I go out with someone, and who is it?”


“I don’t think it works like that,” Kirishima admits hesitantly. “I thought he could only see the actions of the person he touched...not who else is with them.”


“Oh, bummer!” Kaminari pouts, then smiles again, looking at Midoriya and asking, “So, will you do it?”


Midoriya sighs, and then stands. Fingers drumming on the table slowly, he says, “I suppose I can play along, just this once. I do not have any pressing cases that require my Quirk at the moment, only my brain. Very well. Give me your hand.”


Kaminari juts out his hand, and Midoriya gives him a look of exasperation, sighing once again.


Then Midoriya takes the hand presented to him, and his eyes glow purple, clocklike designs appearing within. Midoriya hums, tilting his head, eyes almost distant as they perceive the person before him.


“You will die in seven days,” Midoriya says, voice eerie and dry, and Kaminari lets go with a yelp.


“What the 

fuck

!” Kaminari screams, and Midoriya lets out a chuckle.


“It’s only a joke,” Midoriya says plainly. “Good luck on your next sparring match, Kaminari.”


Needless to say, Kaminari moves cautiously for the next week.


The rest of the day goes rather smoothly, all things considered, or perhaps even without considering the variables of the present. Lunch goes well, with Midoriya eating calmly beside Toshinori Yagi, who cannot refrain from taking photos and sending them to the man being impersonated- a fact that will lead to a stoic man smiling, another hint of a bridge being rebuilt with time and dedication- as he marvels at his successor. And this chance to see Midoriya before class gives Yagi the ability to teach heroics without faltering, nothing going amiss, not with Midoriya having already used Mirai Sasaki’s Quirk on Kaminari, no longer usable after the hour had passed.


And so the day ends not with a bang, but with a calm finale, the bell ringing and allowing Midoriya to seamlessly transition back into himself, a smiling ray of joy incarnate as he looks upon his peers.


“I made it through the day,” Midoriya says, eyes sparkling with the realization, and his joy is infectious for the rest of 1-A.


All in all, it is a good day.


-----


And a great Thursday turns into a wonderful Friday, with the students of 1-A bouncing from either anticipation or excitement as they reach Nemuri Kayama’s class.


Not that Nemuri could ever judge her students. Not when she, too, has been looking forward to seeing what they will bring to the table, so to speak.


Project presentations begin the moment that Nemuri steps into the room, and if one were to ask her later on, she'd say that she's proud of her students for meeting her expectations- and, for some, even surpassing them. 


Shinsou’s presentation, for one, easily earns quite a few laughs out of her, the boy rating Yuuei's different spaces by how often Shouta Aizawa fell asleep there- with pictures to reference, of course- before hopping into a more legitimate speech on the problems that come with sleep deprivation as proof on why Shouta shouldn't be interrupted during his naps.


"Just look at the difference," Shinsou finishes, clicking to a slide with four pictures. The first side has a picture of Shouta sleeping, but it's crossed out, and an arrow points to an angry, red-eyed Shouta as the next image, a direct correlation of sleeplessness and rage. The third image is one that makes 1-A coo, a picture of Shouta and Midoriya in matching sleeping bags, fast asleep, and an arrow leads to a picture of a slightly smiling Shouta. "In conclusion, let Aizawa sleep, but especially in the classroom and teacher's lounge, because I'm pretty sure he expelled a kid once for tripping over him in the hallway."


Yes, Shinsou’s presentation instantly takes a spot as one of Nemuri’s favorites, due to its ability to humor her, but there are two others that are especially notable to the R-rated hero.


The next has to be Todoroki’s, due to the boy’s lack of nerves as he once again makes it clear to his peers where his affections lay.


"My project is on the most important people in my life, and why they deserve the title," Todoroki explains upon his project appearing onto the screen, and promptly jumps into a slideshow covered in pictures.


And oh, how Nemuri wants to squeal in delight, seeing who Todoroki shows upon the screen. Because at first it is the boy's mother, and Todoroki praises her with love clearly in his heart. And then Todoroki moves on, showing a few slides with his siblings upon it and speaking of their influence on him.


But then the boy switches to a picture of Midoriya, and something shifts. And Nemuri would have to be blind, or as oblivious as Midoriya appears to be when it comes to matters of the heart, to miss the way that Todoroki softens, words filled with admiration and adoration as he spends more than half of his time simply talking about his peer, waxing poetry about the boy's greatest traits.


And although Midoriya may miss the connection, may not realize that Todoroki has only spoken about people who he loves, Nemuri can see how red faced and teary eyed the boy has become, a sign that Todoroki’s words have flustered him. And that's a start, Nemuri supposes.


And then comes the third project that comes to mind the most. Midoriya’s project, being presented right after Todoroki’s near confession of a speech.


Midoriya, Nemuri has always known, is a bright mind wrapped in a kind soul. She's scored his papers, his analyses of art that she's shown the class. Understanding and learning come quickly to him, and it's of no surprise to Nemuri that the boy knows a 

lot

.


But Midoriya has always been rather timid, when forced into the spotlight. Speeches made him shake, and presentations made him panic.


Or, rather, they used to. But then the spotlight became something else to Midoriya, something better. Acting under Aizawa’s assignments helped the boy flourish, helped him embrace the confidence lurking within.


And so when Midoriya's turn comes up, he does not even hesitate to begin, and it is this confidence that sticks in Nemuri’s head, this clear sign of growth.


“I was going to teach you guys about analysis," Midoriya starts, voice nonchalant yet excited, "but that didn’t sound very fun- not for you guys, at least. However, I am rather good at a skill that relies heavily on talent and analysis, and that’s what I’ll be talking about today!”


Midoriya clicks on a remote- one that Nemuri doesn't remember him grabbing, now that she thinks about it- and a slideshow pops up.


"Let's talk about acting!" Midoriya chirps, and so they do exactly that.


And Midoriya takes the stage, so to speak, starting off strong by explaining all of the ways one can act, its uses and types and even its origins. And this is all well and good, this is the informative speech Nemuri asked for, but it is also only the start.


Because then Midoriya applies it to himself.


"Now, if I were to fit myself into one of these definitions, which one would you guys apply to me?" And Midoriya gestures to the slide, definitions covering the page, and smiles invitingly at his peers.


And Kirishima responds, shouting out, "You're a method actor, right?"


Midoriya beams, then knocks his fists together, the limbs hardening right as they collide. "You got it!" Midoriya cheers, and the sudden Quirk usage is enough to get 1-A perked up, drawn right into Midoriya’s presentation, an attentive audience for their actor.


Midoriya drops the Quirk, the persona, and flashes a blinding smile. "The best definition 

would

 be method actor, considering how I don't break character when given assignments, and that my Quirk can only work if I'm portraying someone else." 


Changing slides, Midoriya asks, "I've given you guys a lot of information on the benefits of acting. Which ones can be applied to heroics?"


And the students of 1-A heed his call, hands raising and answers on the tips of their tongues, much to Nemuri’s delight. Because participation is voluntary, their interactions with the projects of their peers have no influence on their grades, and yet over half of the class is eager to get involved.


And Midoriya rewards this decision, acting as whichever peer offers an answer, using his Quirk to mimic theirs.


"Acting could help you infiltrate an area," Uraraka says, and Midoriya nods, hands closing around the remote before opening up.


"Exactly!" Midoriya says, ignoring the way that the remote floats upwards, untethered by gravity. "Being a good actor would allow you to sneak into places otherwise untouchable!" Midoriya glances upwards, then flushes. "Oh, my bad!" Fingers press together, and a cry of "Release!" is enough for the remote to drop back into Midoriya’s hand, the persona dropping away the moment plastic meets skin.


"Right, who's next?"


And Nemuri could keep going, truly, could keep describing how Midoriya proceeds to mimic a third of his class, praising them in their own character before using their Quirks to heighten their excitement, but, really, there's only one more that Nemuri feels the urge to note.


"Being able to act would allow you to have a persona, so that you can make yourself and others feel comfortable," Todoroki offers, and Midoriya blinks before smiling ever so softly, a grin that's barely there but genuine, a Todoroki grin.


"Perfectly said," Midoriya responds, ice forming in one hand, frosting over the remote. 


And then Midoriya pauses, eyes catching on his own desk and staying there.


And then Midoriya is snapping out of it, persona dropping and smile growing. And he finishes up his presentation, wrapping it up and thanking his peers for their involvement.


Face growing oddly red all the while.


But Nemuri does not ask, does not press, because she has a feeling that she knows perfectly well what has just happened, what has been realized. And Midoriya seems perplexed by this information, stunned by the new comprehension of the world that he has...but not upset.


Not upset in the slightest.


And so Nemuri Kayama lets her class finish in peace, and then offers the rest of the class as a free period, reveling in the way that Todoroki and Midoriya instantly begin to speak with one another.


Neither will make a move, she knows, Todoroki too scared by Aizawa and Midoriya too new to this knowledge, but that is quite alright.


Nemuri has always been a fan of slow burns, after all.


(And so the week ends on a high note, full of joy.


And perhaps the start of something more, but only time will tell that tale.)
